messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "tea taste" style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... I wonder if this tsuba fulfills the wabi sabi and tea taste criterion??? http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/09a_NOB_TSUBA.jpg It is a
messages.messageBody:
Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Look up ca. Momoyama tea ceramics in Raku, Shino, Oribe,
> Iga, Seto, Mino, Shigaraki, etc., styles. There's a lot more to
> tea taste than that, but it will be a start.

I wonder if this tsuba fulfills the "wabi sabi" and "tea taste" criterion???

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/09a_NOB_TSUBA.jpg

It is a tsuba from a handachi in very lovely, subdued koshirae - dark ishime
lacquer with black fuchigashira and an iron plate instead of same. The plate
has a nunome zogan dragon down each side of the tsuka. I would welcome opinions
on the mumei tsuba. Here and there on the surface one can see tiny blobs of
gold. I think they represent dew drops on the "rotted wood" of the iron surface
of the tsuba. I apologise for the poor quality of the image. I took it years
ago with a "first edition" digital camera. I should do it again - and both
sides - however, I just wanted to get things going here. I think the tsuba is
Tosa Myochin but - what do I know!!! I based this opinion on the tagane style
on the seppa dai that I once read was a characteristic of Tosa Myochin...

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "tea taste" style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: David, Look up ca. Momoyama tea ceramics in Raku, Shino, Oribe, Iga, Seto, Mino, Shigaraki, etc., styles.  There s a lot more to tea taste than that, but it
messages.messageBody:
David,
Look up ca. Momoyama tea ceramics in Raku, Shino, Oribe, Iga, Seto, Mino, Shigaraki, etc., styles. There's a lot more to tea taste than that, but it will be a start.

I think that your idea about debris might have come from terms like gomoku zogan used to describe late, low quality, "random" decoration sometimes retrofitted to older plates. I don't think that there was any intention to actually depict debris or puddles. Tea leaves -- no. That style of tea is actually a bright green, fine powder, btw.

I don't see anything Tenbo about the plate, but to your earlier question, there are some Tenbo guards with Yamashiro ju signatures, so presumably there was a relationship with Kyoto at some point. Who knows where the many poor quality mu-mei ones from later in the Edo period were made.

Jim



My question was meant to ask how does a Sahari-decorated Tenpo school tsuba achieve "tea taste" style? I had the impression that surfaces decorated with irregular non-clearly representational lumps and patches of mixed-metal solder were intended to resemble beach debris, the bottom of forest mud puddles, or tidal pools. Is it possible that tsuba were decorated to resemble used tea leaves at the bottom of a tea pot or tea cup?



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:
My question was meant to ask how does a Sahari-decorated Tenpo school tsuba achieve "tea taste" style? I had the impression that surfaces decorated with irregular non-clearly representational lumps and patches of mixed-metal solder were intended to resemble beach debris, the bottom of forest mud puddles, or tidal pools. Is it possible that tsuba were decorated to resemble used tea leaves at the bottom of a tea pot or tea cup?


----- Original Message -----
From: chris bowen
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Saturday, July 30, 2005 5:43 PM
Subject: Re: "tea taste" style tsuba


I would imagine it is referring to the aesthetics of the tea ceremony, which under Toyotomi's patronage and Sen no Rikkyu's execution (no pun intended), was at the height of popularity during the Momoyama era....


On Jul 30, 2005, at 7:29 PM, David Zincavage wrote:


Item 20 in Haynes Catalogue 9, s tembo-style tsuba with brazed decoration, is described as a "tea taste" style tsuba of the Momoyama period. Can anyone describe the characteristics and history of tea taste tsuba?



--
Sincerely,

Chris Bowen
